awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Orbital Forcing of South Indian Hydroclimate
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to address a deficit of orbital-scale speleothem data from India regarding the Indian Summer Monsson (ISM). The project focusses on cave deposits from southern India, south of the Himalayas, where the impact of the monsoon is greatest.

The scientific rationale for the research is designed to address the following hypotheses: 1) orbital variations force rainfall changes by uniformly affecting the global monsoon; 2) Chinese stalagmite records reflect upstream source changes related to ISM amplitude; and 3) regional climate dynamics, in addition to variations in local summer insolation, contributes substantially to ISM variability. 

The broader impacts involve examining the Indian Monsoon as a key aspect of the global climate system, international science collaboration, support of an early career postdoctoral scholar, and outreach in public lectures through Science Under the Stars in Austin, Texas.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Asian monsoon brings rain to billions of people and is vital for the health and economy of much of the world. Additionally, seasonal monsoon precipitation fuels biogeochemical change across Asia as well as the northern Indo-Pacific oceanic sector, which can, in turn, significantly impact the global carbon budget. Cave records from Asia are excellent archives to investigate past changes in monsoon activity and show how monsoon intensity has changed naturally over the past hundred to hundreds of thousands of years. Of particular interest is the sensitivity of the Asian monsoon to changes in solar radiation due to shifts in the Earth's orbit over tens of thousands of years. In our research, we show that this timescale of orbital change is directly associated with shorter-term 'abrupt'-scale changes in the composition of methane in the atmosphere - a diagnostic parameter of the global carbon cycle. Although monsoon intensity has been thought to play a key role in controlling past changes in methane, our research points to a decoupling between the two, and we suggest that changes in the monsoon are not so straight-forward. Instead, abrupt monsoon changes are governed by complex interactions in the climate system that do not seem to vary across the same periodicities as abrupt changes in atmospheric methane, and therefore, its associated limb of carbon cycling. Curiously, our research also uncovers a strong increasing trend in the intensity of abrupt-scale climate change events since the past 400 thousand years, where we demonstrate synchronous changes between caves records of the Asian monsoon and ice core climate reconstructions from Antarctica. We also show that over these timescales, the large-scale Asian monsoon phenomenon does not change equivalently across the entire continent. Instead, there are regions that behave independently, such as peninsular South India versus mainland China, both regions that experience strong summer monsoon rainfall today. Our results support the inference that the Asian monsoon response to changes associated with past ice age cycles was not uniform across Asia. Moreover, our work suggests that the magnitude of opposing seasonal monsoon changes, i.e.,changes in the summer versus winter monsoons, over this timescale are not uniform either. Today, much of the Indian subcontinent is dominated by summer monsoon rainfall that occurs from June to September; a small subset of coastal peninsular and northwestern regions experience winter rainfall in November and December that can rival summer totals. Using cave records from southern India, we show that this observed balance of summer and winter rainfall was not the same over time, with evidence for stronger winter monsoons during colder ice ages that penetrated further inland into peninsular India. On the other hand, peninsular Indian summer monsoon was relative weaker during these intervals. Finally, during warmer periods between ice ages (such as the current Holocene epoch we live in today), our research suggests that the winter monsoon was weak but that Indian summer monsoon intensity was strong and more sensitive to changes in solar radiation.
